WTF SE is now even considering to autodelete all comments after 21 days or something?! 
And at best this would be also implemented in the whole network without giving individual communities the possibility to decide if the want this, as it is always done with such unneeded very drastic intrusive negative software changes (the darn automated downvotes come to mind)?

This would be terribly bad...

SE should consider to just autogenerate questions and answers to the different site topics by scripts on each site too, such that no real people would be needed and the Q&A library for Googlers would be really clean enough, without any signs of real communities/people living on each site

Two thoughts:

1) Auto-deleting comments after any period of days is a demonstrably bad idea.

2) Bring back Home Automation >:-(

Regarding autodelete...

The reason this would be beneficial is that MANY of the comments that are posted are rubbish and actually detract from the perceived value of the site.

The reason this would be detrimental is that there are some really good comments out there which add value to the site, but do not work well in an answer or edit.

The goal is really to clean out the rubbish without losing the value-adding content, so how do we do that? Actually, you already have a metric you cold use for that: votes provide us with a very good indication of how valuable a comment is. However, it can take time to accrue votes.

So here is my proposal: Autodelete any comment which has less than 1 up-vote per month (for example.)

I don't know if you have statistics on this, but I suspect that the majority of readers of this blog post do not listen to the entire podcast. They stop by to read the bullet points, and go away with the impression that this is an accurate description of what was said on the podcast. 

The remark about auto-deletion of comments after 21 days makes it look like an actual proposal being discussed. It was all strictly hypothetical, "if we started over from scratch", "in an alternate universe"... but most readers of the post won't know because they don't listen to the podcast.
